Executive Summary - City of Lewiston Water Treatment Plant Executive Summary

The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy at your Facility

The City's Water Treatment Plant employees are trained in:

Chemical First Responders Course
Use of Class "A" (150 lb repair kit) and "B" (one ton repair kit) chlorine repair kits
Use of SCBA (self contained breathing apparatus)
First Aid and CPR

The City of Lewiston and the Water Treatment Plant has set up an emergency response plan to minimize injury to people, property, and the environment.  This emergency plan utilizes the Incident Command System (ICS) and incorporates a three phase training cycle.  Further details on the training program are provided in the following section titled "Emergency Response Program"

The Facility and the Regulated Substance Handled 

The City of Lewiston's Water Treatment Plant Facility is located at 2901 Rail Road, Lewiston Idaho.  The water treatment plant is located on the Clearwater River.  The plant is located one mile west of Potlatch Corporation, 120' south of the Clearwater River, 0.5 miles east of Highway 12 and 0.25 miles north of a residential and industrial area.

The plant treats 2.0-15.0 million gallons daily to service the greater Lewiston area.  The population served is approximately 13,500.  Chemicals are used in the following processes:

Pre-chlorination - Chlorine
Coagulation - alum and lime (aluminum sulfate and calcium carbonate)
Sedimentation - none
Filtration - none
Post fluoridation - sodium silica fluoride
Post pH adjustment - lime (calcium carbonate)
Post chlorination - chlorine
Pumped into the distribution system

The regulated substance is 8,000 pounds of chlorine stored in four, one-ton cylinders liquefied under pressure.  Operators are on duty minimum 10 to maximum 24 hours per day, seven days per week.  One cylinder of liquid chlorine under pressure furnishes the necessary gas/water mixture to disinfect the influent and effluent (pre and post).

Two operators are always present during the transfer of cylinders to and from storage to be utilized for disinfection.
The storage and dispensing areas are located in an enclosed building of masonry construction.

Emergency Response Program

The Lewiston water treatment plant has a three-phase employee training cycle.  The first phase is classroom instruction on chemical release prevention and response.  Employees learn (or refresh) themselves on the basics.  A trainer spends time necessary to ensure fundamentals of chemical transportation, storage, use of a class "A" and class "B" repair kits, use of self contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), first response, first aid, and CPR certified, use of emergency operations plan, and action guide are known by all personnel.

The second phase is to exercise the skills they have learned.  Having drills on specific tasks, i.e., putting on the SCBA and using the "B" kit perform this.  Drills are conducted until all facility-operating personnel are proficient at their tasks.

The third phase is testing the emergency operations plan and skills that the employees learned.  This is accomplished by conducting a full-scale exercise.  During this exercise local emergency res

ponse and recovery agencies are involved.

After the third phase is completed an "After Action Review (AAR) is conducted.  The AAR may result in changes to the emergency operations plan.  Once the plan has been revised, the process will start again on phase one.

The current emergency response plan consists of two elements:

Emergency action guide
Emergency response plan

The Emergency Action Guide is a quick action checklist that consists of emergency responders phone numbers and immediate action steps to protect life, property, and the environment.

The Emergency Operations Plan is a details plan that gives further considerations and steps to be taken in the event of an emergency.

Planned Change to Improve Safety

Exercising the emergency operations plan in the form of a disaster exercise.  

Continue activity in the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) to remain acquainted with community emergency response activities and programs.
